elements.content: A polycyclic imidazolophosphinine has been synthesized by collapse of the bridge of an appropriate 7-phosphanorbornene. This stable compound has been characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis. It is fully planar with a PC bond length of 1.733(4) Å. The lone pair at P is poorly reactive and corresponds to HOMO–3. The compound reacts with a protic acid and methyl iodide at the sp2 nitrogen and with AuCl with the α-methoxy substituent, yielding a zwitterionicacylphosphidewhose complexation at P gives a bis-gold complex. Both the protonated product and the bis-gold complex have been characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis.

elements.content: A typical aromatic sp2 nitrogen as in pyridine is a mild base (pK a ca. +5), whereas an aromatic sp2 phosphorus as in phosphinine is a strong electrophilic center. These strikingly different behaviors are easily rationalized by a comparison of the orbital schemes of pyridine and phosphinine. These data explain why there are not so many molecules in the literature containing both types of heteroatomiccenters. Even the simple pyridylphosphinines are known but poorly studied due to the limited number and stability of these molecules. Both for exploring new annelated phosphinines and to add data concerning the comparison of the chemistry of aromatic sp2 nitrogen and phosphorus, we decided to start an investigation of the synthesis and properties of the so far unknown imdazolophosphinines.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A typical aromatic sp2 nitrogen as in pyridine is a mild base (pK a ca. +5), whereas an aromatic sp2 phosphorus as in phosphinine is a strong electrophilic center. These strikingly different behaviors are easily rationalized by a comparison of the orbital schemes of pyridine and phosphinine. These data explain why there are not so many molecules in the literature containing both types of heteroatomiccenters. Even the simple pyridylphosphinines are known but poorly studied due to the limited number and stability of these molecules. Both for exploring new annelated phosphinines and to add data concerning the comparison of the chemistry of aromatic sp2 nitrogen and phosphorus, we decided to start an investigation of the synthesis and properties of the so far unknown imdazolophosphinines.

Results and Discussion

Our synthetic approach has been similar to our already reported synthesis of a phosphorus analogue of acenaphthylene. We use the collapse of the phosphorus bridge of a 7-phosphanorbornene to create the desired phosphorus heterocycle. The starting organic product was prepared as shown in .

elements.content:
The cleavage of the phosphanorbornene bridge of 5 was performed by HCl as generated in situ from aluminum trichloride in THF. The dehydrochlorination of 6 then gave the phosphinine 8 ().

The mechanism probably involves a carbocation formed from the CH­(OMe)2 unit that reacts with the phosphorus lone pair to build the P–C bond. The cleavage itself probably proceeds via a pentacoordinate species that collapses via a retro-McCormack reaction.

elements.content: Imidazolophosphinine 8 is a stable yellow solid which shows a 31P resonance at 73 ppm in deuterochloroform. This resonance at relatively high field results from the presence of the methoxy substituent on the PC double bond. As expected, the 13C resonance of the PC double bond appears at very low field (188.96 ppm, 1 J C–P = 48.8 Hz). The phosphinine was further characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis ().

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure analysis of compound 8. Main bond length (Å) and angles (deg): C3–N1 1.399(4); C3–N3 1.320(5); C4–C5 1.434(5); C4–C11 1.396(5); C4–N3 1.366(5); C6–P1 1.780(4); C11–C12 1.417(5); C11–N1 1.397(5); C12–P1 1.733(4) ; C12–P1–C6 101.37(18).

The structural data of the phosphinine ring (C–P–C angle, P–C bond lengths) are remarkably close to those of 2-phosphaphenol showing that the annelation has no influence on the structure. In order to have a deeper insight in the electronic structure of 8, we performed a DFT study of the phosphinine at the B3PW91/6-311+G­(d,p) level. The computed structure is very close to the experimental one. The orbital scheme gives some indication on the reactivity of the molecule ().

elements.content: As expected, the PC­(O) double bond substantially contributes to the LUMO and the HOMO. The HOMO–1 and −2 are also π orbitals. The P-lone pair appears in HOMO–3. Hence, it will display a rather low reactivity, thus explaining the good stability of 8.

elements.content: Compounds 9 and 11 were characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis ( and ). The protonation exclusively takes place at the sp2 nitrogen and does not modify the structural parameters around phosphorus. The Lewis acidic gold chloride initially reacts at oxygen, inducing the cleavage of the O–methyl bond. The resulting acylphosphide is complexed at P by two gold chlorides. The P1–C9 distance is 1.847 Å within the range of the P–C single bond, and the length of C9–O1 is reduced to 1.221 Å which falls into the normal range of CO double bonds. At 3.014 Å, the gold–gold distance falls within the range of the gold–gold aurophilic interactions. An infinite zigzag chain of [L­(AuCl)2] n is held by the aurophilic interaction ().

X-ray crystal structure analysis of compound 11. Main bond length (Å) and angles (deg): Au2–Au11 3.0143(3); Au1–P1 2.2509(13); Au1–Cl1 2.3107(15); P1–C9 1.847(6); C8–C7 1.373(7); P1–C1 1.814(5); C8–C9 1.432(7); C1–C6 1.413(7); C9–O1 1.221(6); Au2–P1–Au1 108.66(5); C1–P1–C9 104.4(2).

We have successfully synthesized the first imidazolophosphinine via the cleavage of the bridge of the appropriate 7-phosphanorbornene. The compound is remarkably stable. Its planarity and its π HOMO and LUMO suggest a possible use in stacked charge transfer complexes. Its reactivity toward protic acids, methyl iodide and gold chloride involves either sp2 nitrogen or oxygen and is clearly under charge control. Reactions at the π system remain to be explored.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized the first imidazolophosphinine via the cleavage of the bridge of the appropriate 7-phosphanorbornene. The compound is remarkably stable. Its planarity and its π HOMO and LUMO suggest a possible use in stacked charge transfer complexes. Its reactivity toward protic acids, methyl iodide and gold chloride involves either sp2 nitrogen or oxygen and is clearly under charge control. Reactions at the π system remain to be explored.

elements.content: All reactions were routinely performed under an inert atmosphere of nitrogen by using standard Schlenk techniques and dry deoxygenated solvents. Dry THF was obtained by distillation from Na/benzophenone. Dry toluene was obtained by distillation from P4O10. n-Butyl lithium (1.6 M in hexane) was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. Neutral aluminum oxide for TLC (100–200 mesh) was purchased from Kermel Co. Ltd., and silica gel (200–300 mesh) from Qingdao Hai Yang Chemical Industry Co. Ltd. was used for chromatographic separations. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were recorded on a Bruker 300 MHz spectrometer operating at 300.13 MHz for 1H, 75.468 MHz for 13C, and 121.495 MHz for 31P. Chemical shifts are expressed from internal TMS (1H and 13C). All coupling constants (J values) are reported in hertz (Hz). HRMS were obtained on an Agilent 1290–6540 Q-Tof spectrometer by electrospray ionization (ESI). Given the high sensitivity of the new compounds, the small scale of their syntheses, the formation of clear solutions for NMR analysis, and the excellent agreement of the NMR spectra with the crystal structures, the general purity of the compounds based on NMR spectroscopy are acceptable.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information and Materials

All reactions were routinely performed under an inert atmosphere of nitrogen by using standard Schlenk techniques and dry deoxygenated solvents. Dry THF was obtained by distillation from Na/benzophenone. Dry toluene was obtained by distillation from P4O10. n-Butyl lithium (1.6 M in hexane) was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. Neutral aluminum oxide for TLC (100-200 mesh) was purchased from Kermel Co. Ltd., and silica gel (200-300 mesh) from Qingdao Hai Yang Chemical Industry Co. Ltd. was used for chromatographic separations. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were recorded on a Bruker 300 MHz spectrometer operating at 300.13 MHz for 1H, 75.468 MHz for 13C, and 121.495 MHz for 31P. Chemical shifts are expressed from internal TMS (1H and 13C). All coupling constants (J values) are reported in hertz (Hz). HRMS were obtained on an Agilent 1290-6540 Q-Tof spectrometer by electrospray ionization (ESI). Given the high sensitivity of the new compounds, the small scale of their syntheses, the formation of clear solutions for NMR analysis, and the excellent agreement of the NMR spectra with the crystal structures, the general purity of the compounds based on NMR spectroscopy are acceptable.

elements.content: To a solution of 1 (2.7 g, 10 mmol) in CHCl3 (30 mL), the Vilsmeier–Haack reagent (prepared from POCl3 and DMF in CHCl3) was added at 0 °C. The mixture was heated for 4 h at 60 °C, then cooled to room temperature and treated with saturated NaOH solution in water until the pH rose to 6. The organic compounds were extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 20 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with saturated NaHCO3 solution (3 × 10 mL) and water (20 mL), then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 4:1) to afford product 2 (2.7 g, 90%) as a white powder. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.16 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 1H), 7.27–7.38 (m, 1H), 7.42–7.48 (m, 1H),7.54–7.72 (m, 2H), 7.75 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 9.60 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 9.76 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ 115.59 (s, CH), 117.72 (s, CH), 121.06 (s, C), 123.38 (s, C), 127.40 (s, CH), 128.57 (s, CH), 130.19 (s, CH), 130.98 (s, CH), 132.49 (s, CH), 133.32 (s, CH), 133.45 (s, C), 147.53 (s, C), 156.89 (s, C), 179.32 (s, CH). To a solution of 1 (2.7 g, 10 mmol) in CHCl3 (30 mL), the Vilsmeier–Haack reagent (prepared from POCl3 and DMF in CHCl3) was added at 0 °C. The mixture was heated for 4 h at 60 °C, then cooled to room temperature and treated with saturated NaOH solution in water until the pH rose to 6. The organic compounds were extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 20 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with saturated NaHCO3 solution (3 × 10 mL) and water (20 mL), then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 4:1) to afford product 2 (2.7 g, 90%) as a white powder. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.16 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 1H), 7.27–7.38 (m, 1H), 7.42–7.48 (m, 1H),7.54–7.72 (m, 2H), 7.75 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 9.60 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 9.76 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ 115.59 (s, CH), 117.72 (s, CH), 121.06 (s, C), 123.38 (s, C), 127.40 (s, CH), 128.57 (s, CH), 130.19 (s, CH), 130.98 (s, CH), 132.49 (s, CH), 133.32 (s, CH), 133.45 (s, C), 147.53 (s, C), 156.89 (s, C), 179.32 (s, CH). Synthesis of Compound <bold>3</bold>

A solution of 2 (1.5 g, 5 mmol), trimethylorthoformate (2.05 g, 20 mmol), and TsOH (75 mg, 0.4 mmol, 8%) in methanol (50 mL) was refluxed at 60 °C for 4 h until total consumption of the starting aldehyde as monitored by TLC (CH2Cl2/hexane = 1:3). After removal of methanol, the reaction mixture was extracted with diethyl ether, and the organic layer was dried with MgSO4. After evaporation of the solvent, the crude product was chromatographed on silica gel (CH2Cl2/hexane = 1:3) to afford a pure faint yellow oil, 3 (1.5 g, yield: 88%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 3.32 (s, 6H), 5.31 (s, 1H), 6.77–6.82 (m, 1H), 7.18–7.28 (m, 2H), 7.33–7.38 (m, 1H), 7.42–7.46 (m, 1H),7.60–7.68 (m, 2H), 8.58 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ 55.21 (s, 2OCH3), 100.25 (s, CH), 112.26 (s, CH), 117.50 (s, CH), 117.75 (s, C), 123.98 (s, C), 125.35 (s, CH), 126.97 (s, CH), 127.03 (s, CH), 129.88 (s, CH), 132.44 (s, CH), 132.82 (s, CH), 135.22 (s, C), 144.64 (s, C), 145.14 (s, C). HRMS: m/z calculated for C16H16BrN2O2 (M + H+) 347.0390, found 347.0397.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>4</bold>

To a THF (50 mL) solution of 3 (1.73 g, 5 mmol), n-BuLi (3.3 mL, 1.6 M, 5.25 mmol) was added at −78 °C. The resulting solid was washed with hexane to give desired complex 10 (white solid, 144 mg, yield: 63%). 31P NMR (DMSO-d 6) δ 101.6; 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 4.34 (d, 3H, OCH3), 4.55 (s, 3H, CH3), 7.69-7.77 (m, 2H), 7.85 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 8.33-8.55 (m, 2H), 8.75 (d, J = 9.5 Hz, 1H), 8.96 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 9.84 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 36.62 (s, CH3), 60.27 (d, J C-P = 29.1 Hz, OCH3), 111.67 (s, CH), 118.63 (s, CH), 121.18 (d, J C-P = 300.2 Hz, C), 122.10 (d, J C-P = 12.2 Hz, C), 125.84 (s, CH), 127.61 (d, J C-P = 21.0 Hz, CH), 128.95 (d, J C-P = 4.0 Hz, CH), 132.40 (s, CH), 133.90 (d, J C-P = 6.9 Hz, C), 135.15 (d, J C-P = 47.3 Hz, CH), 137.80 (s, CH), 141.84 (s, C), 146.64 (d, J C-P = 46.3 Hz, C), 187.43 (d, J C-P = 46.5 Hz, C). HRMS: m/z calculated for C16H14N2OP (M - OTf-)+ 281.0838, found 281.0842.

Synthesis of Compound 11 

To a stirred solution of pure 8 (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) in dichloromethane (10 mL) was added AuCl (THT, 320 mg, 1 mmol) at room temperature. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, DMSO (5 mmol) was dropped slowly at room temperature. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated. The resulting solid was washed with hexane to give desired complex 11 (yellow solid, 226 mg, yield: 63%). Single crystals were obtained in DMSO and Et2O. 31P NMR (DMSO-d 6) δ -8.3; 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 4.99 (br, s, 1H), 7.38 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, J = 6.8 Hz, 1H), 7.55-7.58 (m, 2H), 7.71-7.84 (m, 2H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 8.45-8.49 (m, 1H), 9.47 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 117.03 (s, CH), 117.38 (s, CH), 119.48 (d, J C-P = 50.1 Hz, C), 126.72 (d, J C-P = 5.1 Hz, CH), 129.27 (s, CH), 129.62 (d, J C-P = 1.5 Hz, CH), 129.94 (d, J C-P = 13.7 Hz, CH), 130.03 (s, C), 132.96 (s, CH), 133.23 (d, J C-P = 18.3 Hz, CH), 136.79 (d, J C-P = 28.5 Hz, C), 148.24 (s, C), 153.04 (d, J C-P = 1.5 Hz, C), 192.49 (d, J C-P = 33.2 Hz, C). HRMS: m/z calculated for C14H9Au2Cl2N2NaOP (M + Na+) 738.9053, found 738.9052.
